##Strategy

[[☃ image 1]]

In time, $\Delta t$, the net charge that passes through a cross-section, $I\Delta t$, equals the charge contained in the volume, $\redD{|\bold v_d|\Delta t}\times\blue{l^2}$.

Given the number density of charge carriers, $n$, what is the net charge in a volume? That should lead us to the answer.

##Solution

$\begin{align} 
I\cancel{\Delta t} &= \overbrace{ne}^{\text{charge density}}\times\overbrace{\redD{|\bold v_d|}\ \cancel{\redD{\Delta t}}\ \blue{l^2}}^{\text{volume}}\\\\
\Rightarrow I&=ne|\bold v_d|l^2\\\\
\Rightarrow l^2&=\dfrac{I}{ne|\bold v_d|}\\\\
&=\dfrac{3.6\ \text A}{10^{30}\ \text m^{-3}\times1.6\times10^{-19}\ \text C\times 10^{-5}\ \dfrac{\text m}{\text s}}\\\\
&=2.25\times10^{-6}\ \text m^2\\\\
\Rightarrow l&=1.5\times10^{-3}\ \text m\\\\
&=1.5\ \text{mm}
\end{align}$

question.content:
A metal conductor with a square cross-section of side, $l$, carries a current, $I=3.6\ \text A$. 

The metal has $10^{30}$ free electrons per $\text m^3$ drifting slowly at $10^{-5}\ \dfrac{\text m}{\text s}$.

**What is the length, $l$, of each side of the conductor?**     
*Note: $e$ $=$ $1.6\times10^{-19}\ \text C$.*
